A warming arctic is not good. As the ice melts the Albedo effect takes place, that means that the ice melts exposing the dark blue water witch absorbs more heat and causing more melting and that’s one big reason why the arctic is warming twice as fast the rest of the globe. Another thing that’s bad is obliviously a warmer arctic means ice melt thus higher sea levels. Earths has already warmed 1C since 1880. But another degree of warming (witch is accepted by 2050) is just enough to melt all of Greenland’s glaciers. Off course all that melting won’t be immediate however it would melt that much over the course of centuries. But don’t have to see centuries for the waters to rise. Sea levels could rise 1-3 meters or 3-9 feet by 2100. That’s enough to flood major cities like New York, London, Miami, Tokyo and much more. Displaying millions even billions. A warmer arctic also means a weaker polar vortex and a slower wavy jet stream. See the jet stream is strong due to big temperature differences, but as the arctic warms so fast, theirs less of a temperature difference so the jet stream becomes wavier, slower, and further south. This means more extreme weather, like droughts, floods, and storms. That couple with the overall Earths temperature being hotter and heat waves will be much more worst. But a weaker, slower, further south, each jet stream could cause a peace of the polar vortex slip south and cause more extreme cold in mid latitudes in some cases. While it’s unknown if they will be more frequent or not especially because global winters a warming really fast, but definitely something possible. And remember the impacts of global warming all start in the arctic, what happens in the arctic dose not stay in the arctic. And as our planet becomes much hotter due to human activity, the North and South Pole will continue to melt and cause extreme weather and other types disasters around the world. One way to fix it is by reducing our carbon footprint and plant more trees, trillions of them. I am but one man, I’m nobody special, I’m just your average citizen, but no longer, my true name is Eric, expect to be hearing it in the very near future, because I absolutely refuse to allow this to continue as long as I’m alive, and I have no plans of going anytime soon. I will not permit this out rage to continue, and while I myself live on long-term disability because of my ill health, there’s nothing wrong with my mind, and thanks to the Internet I have access to everything I need to turn things around. So please join me in attacking our governments. Not physically, but intellectually and financially. Never underestimate the power of one person. One person can make the difference between Trump or Obama, and this particular one person absolutely refuses to allow my government to turn a blind eye to people living in such horrible conditions in my country. If anything it’s not even my country, it’s theirs!!!! They were here thousands of years before my ancestors came, and are the only true real Canadians, along with the native North Americans. I’ve always despised our society for praising the wealthy and punishing the poor, but now they’ve gone to far, I wish I would’ve known about this much sooner, because I will not stop until every last person living there is loud the lifestyle that we all take for granted. Be ready for a big change in the future, I am not shy with my opinions or my beliefs, nothing or nobody can silence me.... every Canadian citizen should be just as outraged as I am, and if you’re not then you do not deserve to live in this country or this planet. We are all brothers and sisters, regardless of where we came from, we all deserve the exact same things in life, nobody is better than anybody else because they have money, money is irrelevant!!!! It’s time we sent a message loud and clear to those rich pricks that control everything, that we will not stand for this any longer. To be honest I’m not quite sure how I will start this campaign, but one way or the other I will start it, and I will not stop until every price tag in every grocery store is the same as it is here in Toronto, and every home that these people live in is as comfortable as the ones we live in. They pay just as much tax as we do, which they shouldn’t have to to begin with, being native citizens! How in the hell can they justify charging $16 for a bag of lettuce in a community where most people are out of work because the climate has been so drastically changed they can no longer sustain their lifestyle like they used to? Stay tuned, and keep my name in your memory, you’ll be hearing a lot of it as I said.

The Supreme Court of Canada has quashed plans for seismic testing in Nunavut, delivering a major victory to Inuit who argued they were inadequately consulted before the National Energy Board gave oil companies the green light to conduct the disruptive activity.

In a unanimous decision handed down Wednesday, written by justices Karakatsanis and Brown, the top court ruled the NEB's consultation process in Clyde River was "significantly flawed" and gave little if any, consideration to the treaty rights of Inuit and their reliance on marine mammals for subsistence.

The Inuit have said the sound wave technology a Norwegian consortium sought to use in search of oil would have profoundly affected marine life in the area."What a victory for us," said Jerry Natanine, a former mayor of Clyde River who pushed this case for years, after the ruling was released. "Justice was on our side because we're fighting for our way of life, our hunting and gathering culture — whaling and sealing — that's our lifestyle, that's what we want to protect."

You mean the Arctic as we know it. All it is is the remaining ice shelf from the Ice Age that enveloped the entire Northern hemisphere, an Ice Age we're currently at the tail end of. This isn't the first time climate change has struck the earth, and it's not the first time there will have been no ice caps on the poles, either. Last time that happened, the earth was covered entirely in plant life that was massive compared to what we have today. The dinosaurs didn't cause climate change in their day, but everything we know about the era from 15 million to 65 million years ago says they did just fine without polar ice caps. Sure, our industrialization sped up the effects of climate change, but "global warming" isn't an anomaly to the planet, and it surely isn't man-made.

This is such a complex issue, I can't take a position. I don't usually agree with Greenpeace's actions but they have a point. Clearly, seismic blasting shouldn't be supported as it negatively affects marine life and the Inuit communities are losing their food sources as a result. At the same time, we need this marine life to maintain a healthy marine ecosystem and allowing commercial hunting threatens the survival of the Arctic. Traditional hunting might be preferable, although I think it is just as cruel (I always have in mind those gory photographs of seal hunts)...

Everything Emma Thompson says at 9:38 resonates deeply with me. I've been thinking exactly those things for quite a while now. It seems insane that people running fossil fuel companies don't seem to care about their children's and grandchildren's futures, but what we need to remember is that (a) some of them (I suspect it's a small but powerful minority) are probably just psychopathic and lack empathy, and (b) those who do want to do the right thing are swimming against a rip tide of corporate momentum and it's nearly impossible for them to have the courage to speak out against the board or the shareholders. I'm not excusing them, I'm just highlighting why there is a problem, and why—as Emma points out—the only way things are going to change is a grass roots movement leading to government legislation. But the government are influenced by oil money too, which is why we're in this Catch 22 situation in which not nearly enough is being done. Removing subsidies to level the playing field with renewables would be a great first step...!

Here is the thing. If we continue using so many fossil fuels, we're screwing over the planet. (BTW, oil isn't the primary fossil fuel contributing to global warming, it's actually coal, which we are gradually using less of). But if we stop using fossil fuels like these people want us to, then we're screwed.

Think about it, our world runs on oil. We use it for transportation, heating and electricity, asphalt, and the production of nearly everything synthetic that we use in today's world. If all the oil in the world were to suddenly vanish, it would be utter chaos. While changing to using "green" energy is the best option, it won't happen quickly, we simply don't have the means currently to power the world with green energy.

Basically, I agree with the message, but you can't expect these things to change quickly. We first have to find a way to develop the technology and at the same time affordably use it to power the world. Until then, like it or not, fossil fuels are here to stay.

How come we don't hear how at the exact same time this is going on, the Antarctic sea ice is at record levels? One growing while the other is shrinking. We only hear about things that will support the "manmade" climate change theory. Years ago, and most people don't know this because it's way before their time, scientists were baffled as to why the polar ice caps on Mars were shrinking at an alarming rate. It was also on the cover of a popular science magazine. Clearly it was not due to "man". Years later the polar caps began to grow in size again. The fact of that matter is, we have no idea what "normal" is, because we have not been on this planet long enough to see how the polar caps changed in size over the past 4.5 billion years. The Earth does, and always will go through climate cycles primarily due to solar activity. You can be 100% assured, that in the past we have had just as extreme or worse weather, earthquakes, floods, droughts, fires, and hurricanes. The weather data we have, only amounts to .0001%. The other 99.9% is unknown. Core samples tell us very little.

Leaving fossil fuels in the ground would condemn BILLIONS of the poorest people including in the arctic to low levels of development. What they need is cheap reliable energy to develop and protect themselves from an already harsh climate. Better buildings, heating, paved roads, ports, etc.

MOST anti-catastrophic climate changers acknowledge that the climate is changing and that we have something to do with it. The Greenhouse Effect is real! Feedback loops could be real. But the models that predict the catastrophies have failed to predict the changing weather. The same "scientists" that are spewing catastrophic climate change claims have been doing so since the 60's (go look at their early articles, seriously). They predicted that much of what they are claiming now would have happened already... TIME FRAME and magnitude MATTERS, period. Look at all the harsh-climate on Earth in which we already thrive; deserts (California, Dubai), swamps (Florida, Bangladesh), below sea level (Netherlands). Its amazing and all brought to you courtesy of cheap, reliable and abundant fossil fuels. Unreliable, "renewables" won't cut it. If you disagree, then really go and do your own research. Don't listen to opinion proxies, YouTubers or celebrities. Go to the source material; read something you don't agree with! New energy is on its way, but for the time being don't rob BILLIONS of people in the developing world the opportunity we've had.

Much of what the Canadian Gov't has done to these people has been an abomination, truly. But their culture and traditional way of life is gone. That is where we stand in 2016 and nothing will bring it back. Furthermore, despite the young girls longing for the old way of life I doubt she would be willing to give up her warm home (for an igloo), her electronics (TV, Internet, I am making an assumption here), her gas-powered Ski-Doo, her father's diesel-powered fishing boat (not exactly traditional) her jet fuel propelled flown-in $6 bottle of Coke (if its in the store then there must be a demand) or her western doctor's. Again, we forced them in many cases and the services are often of poor quality...but do they have better relatively better lives? Most likely. Much of their issues come from not moving on quick enough, developing actual economies or sadly...moving. We all pine for the past, for some pastoral yesteryear that probably wasn't that good to begin with.

Go read Alex Epstein's book the Moral Case for Fossil Fuels...and don't trust him either...check his sources. You won't be disappointed.

Anyways, I definitely see both sides to this. First off, stopping these blasting is not going to stop climate change. I mean, I understand this is more about protecting wildlife but this entire video made it sound like it's about climate change and there's just something about this video that doesn't quite seem logical to me. I've also read the webpage and well... I'm sorry to break the ice, but the technology for renewables just isn't going to cut it.

Don't get me wrong: I really hope that one day renewables can completely replace oil and natural gasses, but I personally don't think that day is coming in the next decade. There's just too many variables in renewables and a lot of engineering problems that still need to be solved. Just, I challenge everyone that's reading this to name one renewable energy that's without a fatal flaw. (As in, will be able to totally replace fossil fuels today, ignoring the politics and even economic part of this equation.) In the meantime, we'll have to keep looking for new reservoirs of oil to keep the globe alive and functioning. Is there seriously no compromise to this? Like, can the oil companies use a different technology? Or maybe blast in frequencies that the marine life can't hear?

Though I suppose Las Vegas is pulling it off pretty well from renewables, so hopefully the rest of the world could catch up.

Thanks to anyone that actually read through this! I'm really open to be able to have a good conversation, and please point out if I'm just wrong on anything in the post.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Here's my list of possible renewable energies:

Solar and wind: When there's no sun or no wind, there's no electricity to be used (Our best battery technology can't store that much energy). Also I just wanted question something: Do the people in the arctic think they could live off solar when they're the ones with the least solar energy?... Solar cell efficiencies are really low. Here's the chart that a lot of people reference: (keep in mind this is the best research cell efficiencies) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_cell_efficiency#/media/File:PVeff(rev160812).jpg

<side_note>
I mean, honestly, if I were the government I'd just provide them with the best solar technology we've got and see if they last even a year. And if they do, great! We're out! But we're also not providing you with anything else. And that's probably what you'd want... No interference! I suppose this is why I'm a science major and not a political scientist.
</side_note>

Nuclear: The public's all up against it worried about nuclear catastrophes, also nuclear waste is a genuine concern. This might actually be the first legit thing we can get from science, although society's pretty against it...

Hydro & tidal: There's just not enough (I think, I don't know a lot about this yet, but I will learn more during this semester!): this can be a really good supplement, but maybe if we put dams in all the rivers in the world it would work? Though that will also affect the wildlife...

The price of food mostly has to do with the cost of getting the food up there especially with produce. Some things like the price difference between coke and pepsi is just an example of super markets trying to promote certain brands. A lot of the times the brands themselves tell them to drop the price by a certain amount and they will subsidize the cost. They do this to gain marketshare, the price might be lower today but a few weeks later it goes back up to the normal price and if you like the product then you will buy it at full price. It does not mean its a good think but its an explanation.

But to go back to the produce you have to remember that it is fairly expensive to transport perishables like fruits an vegetables due to temperature limitations, physical limitation on how rough you can be with them (bruising food/squashing food), and many other variables like the limitation of forms of transport and the cost of that transportation.

Climate change has caused in Saskatchewan a rise in temperature and more rainfall. On the positive side: We have a longer growing season, more land had been able to go into crop productions and we have been able to have better yields (this is in part due to an increase in rainfall).
Also our home heating cost have decreased.
In the past ten years we have had the eight best crop on record.

On the negative side we have had basement flooding problems because our storm drains were not designed to take on the new level from rainstorms. We see crop diseases that we have not seen before.

We see both positive and negative here, but the positive are currently outweighing the negative.
